headline.main: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: FICTION: TRADE: Sunday, February 8th 2009

docs.snippet: After listing the nominees - Eric Roth for "Button," Christopher Nolan for "Dark Knight", John Patrick Shanley for "Doubt," Peter Morgan for "Frost/Nixon" and Simon Beaufoy for "Slumdog", he made the unsurprising announcement that "Slumdog" had wo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Terry George, who's been nominated twice for an Oscar for adapted screenplay ("In the Name of the Father," and "Hotel Rwanda"), first suggested that adapting an existing work was an easy task that involved keeping the start and throwing out the middle part. But then he went on to say it was actually a murderous challenge, that involved writing a movie for the millions who "have an image of that piece of work in their mind and try and put those dreams in a bottle."
docs.abstract: After listing the nominees - Eric Roth for "Button," Christopher Nolan for "Dark Knight", John Patrick Shanley for "Doubt," Peter Morgan for "Frost/Nixon" and Simon Beaufoy for "Slumdog", he made the unsurprising announcement that "Slumdog" had won.

docs.snippet: Simon Beaufoy, the screenwriter of "Slumdog Millionaire," was upstairs at the Millennium Broadway hotel for the cocktail hour. He, like the rest of the people involved in the film, remains surprised that their little movie made in Mumbai seems to ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Simon Beaufoy, the screenwriter of "Slumdog Millionaire," was upstairs at the Millennium Broadway hotel for the cocktail hour before the east coast version of the Writers Guild awards. He, like the rest of the people involved in the film, remains surprised that their little movie made in Mumbai seems to be the leading candidate for best picture at the Oscars.
docs.abstract: Simon Beaufoy, the screenwriter of "Slumdog Millionaire," was upstairs at the Millennium Broadway hotel for the cocktail hour. He, like the rest of the people involved in the film, remains surprised that their little movie made in Mumbai seems to be the leading candidate for best picture at the Oscars.

headline.main: Playing a High-Stakes Game of Risk

docs.snippet: What is the most ridiculous place for a cryptic bird?...
docs.lead_paragraph: I fell in love with crosswords by doing cryptics. Over the years, the kind of wordplay required to solve them has become more common in standard puzzles, and that makes both kinds more fun. I've mentioned this before, but these are the best crosswords to solve with a friend. Sometimes you need to do a little brainstorming to knock aside wrong assumptions or to discover hidden meanings.
docs.abstract: What is the most ridiculous place for a cryptic bird?
